name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: You're making a very valid argument.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Eliminating the Electoral College will be seen as a strictly partisan issue, and it’s not something that can easily happen, while also ignoring the benefits of it.  Talk EC tweaks long term, but Dems need to drop the more extreme and divisive eliminate the EC rhetoric.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text:
That will be the spin, yes, but 60% of Republicans agree that the EC needs to go.  (I think it's 70% of independents and higher still of Dems.)

But, allow me to take the lead from Mayor Pete:  How it is "seen" is less important than "Is it the right thing to do."  It is.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: You can’t just silly nilly throw out major parts of our government structure due to minor issues.  It’s reckless and short sighted. It’s what Republicans were trying to do with eliminating Obamacare.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text:
Um, yes you can amend the Constitution.  

Second, can you name a single instance where the EC has actually functioned as it should, as a safeguard against rash sentiments of the populace?  It distorts elections to favor ONLY swing states and lessens everyone's faith in outcome.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: BTW, in 1913 we amended the Constitution to directly elect the Senate by popular vote instead of by state legislature – a far more impactful change than eliminating the EC.  Not only can it be done, it has been done.  Cheers.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: When two elections in the past 20 years have resulted in the winner of the popular vote losing because of the electoral college, I think that’s kind of a big deal.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Exactly.  And neither of those discordant outcomes were "reasoned" in any way. It was pure chance and sloppy, uneven voting access and systems. No one but the victor gained anything.

reply_text: Wait, so if an 18 year old legal resident of NH is attending Notre Dame in your town, you’re saying they should be able to vote in Indiana?

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Yes. That's how residency works. I moved to PA for college and one of the first things I did was went to the local courthouse and officially changed my voter registration. I lived there the majority of the year for four years, I have a right to have my voice heard where I live.

reply_text: This is nice, but what is your plan for the country if you get the nom? What are your policies? For example:

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Yes policy is important, but most voters don’t follow the individual details of policy. The person who becomes the nominee must have a good head to generate good policy, as well as charisma and good intentions. Warren may have good policy but her personality can be off-putting.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text:
Your first and last sentences are what's wrong with this country.  Liz is warm and engaging and has a myriad of detailed policies to address the mess that Trump's presidency will inevitably leave behind.

 Pete has some merch on his site and a cute bio and ZERO policy. Hard pass.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: I do care about policy but most voters don’t. You can’t intellectualize the vast majority of red state voters. As someone who has lived in red states, I can guarantee that Warren is not going to carry the votes there overall.  If she gets the nomination then I hope I’m wrong!

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: I wasn't insinuating that you don't care nor was I arguing with your (correct) point that most Americans don't care about policy. I don't know if we can tell this early how Warren will do in red states. It will certainly be an uphill battle but I'm not willing to rule her out yet

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: If you support her, then you absolutely should continue to do that. I have already decided that I will vote for whomever the Democratic nominee is whether it is one of the candidates I particularly like or not.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: For me, my conscience won't let me vote for a candidate that doesn't have a clear plan to save this country. It's not enough in post-Trump America to bring empty promises or vague platitudes.  The stakes are much too high. Thank you for the civil discourse.

reply_text: I totally understand your position, but as someone who encountered Trump in NYC in the 90’s, I have no doubt that he and his cronies need to be stopped at all costs. Any democrat would end the court-packing and open racism that this administration has supported.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: You’re not free if you’re beholden to insurance companies and Big Pharma, or if one sudden medical expense bankrupts your family and puts you out on the street. @PeteButtigieg is reclaiming the definition of what “freedom” really means to people. #PeteForAmerica

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: The life of my child with a genetic disorder depends on the protections for those with pre-existing conditions. One of his medications costs more than 25k a month. I will never understand why any American would want to stop the protections for pre-existing conditions.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Before the #ACA I paid $10,000 per MONTH just on meds. I have multiple autoimmune conditions along with mental illnesses that bankrupted me before I was even 25 years old. At 25 my credit was wrecked because I had too many ‘preexisting conditions’.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Protecting well-woman screenings and routine physicals saves lives. So many can’t afford to get  life-saving screenings, so they put it off and need much costlier treatments or die.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text:

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: It needs to go further than ACA.  Freedom means having the means to pay for prescriptions, not just access.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: + Most folks cannot afford an ER visit even on ACA.   They don't visit doctors because of the high deductibles.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Part of the solution is to separate healthcare from the employer. People have their healthcare turned upside down for the whole family if they change jobs. And of course if you lose your job you lose your coverage. COBRA is a joke. If I don't have a job I can't pay $600 a month.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Yes! He's spoken about this on a few different shows. Your insurance should travel with you.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: That's what they say COBRA does, but it's really a joke. Your healthcare shouldn't have to "travel."  It should be independent, stationary, reliable, and never under threat.

name: Pete Buttigieg
reply_text: Well, that's what I meant by travel. It doesn't stay with the company. What he's talked about is your insurance staying with you.

name: Pete Buttigieg
